stem: A 55-year-old man presented to the emergency room with central abdominal pain radiating to his back. examination showed localized central abdominal tenderness. Chest X-ray and lumbar X-ray didn't reveal any abnormality. What is the most likely diagnosis?
disc:
In patients with gall stone-related pancreatitis, the abdominal pain is rapid in onset and localized. In contrast, patients with acute pancreatitis due to alcohol or metabolic causes, present with gradual onset of abdominal pain which is poorly localized. In ~50% of the patients, the pain will radiate to the back. Pain is relieved by sitting up or bending forward.

Physical examination findings include tachycardia, fever, and hypotension. In severe disease, there will be generalized tenderness over the abdomen. There can be features of peritonitis including ileus and distention.

In diverticulitis, usually, the pain is in the lower-left quadrant of the abdomen (involvement of the sigmoid colon). Pain may be on the right side or in the suprapubic region due to the involvement of the caecum.
